trial_identification.studytitle: Improving vitamin D status and related health in young women (part-A)cross-section study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Improving vitamin D status and related health in young women (Part A)-cross-sectional study

interventions.interventions: Investigate the association of circulating 25 OHD levels with Musculoskeletal health Mental health Cardiovascular health

primaryOutcome.outcome: Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with muscle function Muscle function measured by using Leonardo jumping mechanography
Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with weight

secondaryOutcome.outcome: This is a composite secondary outcome: Measure the relationship between 25 OHD levels and UV exposure under Australian conditions, examining both the overall dose and timing of sun exposure UV exposure was assessed using a wearable UV dosimeter
This is primary outcome: Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with mental health Assessed by using a validated PHQ-9 questionnaire
This is primary outcome: Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with body composition Body composition measured by DEXA scan
Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with allergy symptoms Allergy data collected by questionnaire which was designed for the study
Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with bone density Bone density measured by DEXA scan
Association of circulating 25 OHD levels with bone turnover markers, obtained from blood test

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Female 16-25yrs Living in Victoria, Australia Provide informed verbal and written consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pregnant or breastfeeding Plan to move within 2 months of verbal consent

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Medicine, Royal Melbourne Hospital, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052

fundingsource.fundingaddress: National Health and Medical Research Council GPO Box 1421 Canberra ACT 2601

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Level 5, 207 Bouverie Street, The University of Melbourne, VIC 3010
Department of General Practice, The University of Melbourne, 200 Berkeley Street, Carlton VIC 3053
PO Box 2129, Royal Melbourne Hospital, Parkville VIC 3050

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The part A of the Safe-D study involves recruitment of participants into a cross-sectional study in order to investigate the association of vitamin D (25-OHD) levels with clinical health indices and related laboratory measures: musculoskeletal health (bone density, bone turnover markers, muscle function); mood/mental health; body composition and weight; and atopic/allergic symptoms. This study recruited 411 young healthy female aged 16 to 25 years old and living in Victoria, Australia through Facebook advertisement. Wide range of data were collected through completing on line survey questionnaires, attending site visit and wearing of a UV dosimeter.
